title: Dynamic behaviour lab
text:
We study animal behaviour, flight, and animal interactions.
We are located in the Department of Biology at Carleton University in Ottawa, Canada. Research in the lab is led by Dr. Roslyn (Roz) Dakin.
2026: Please get in touch if you would like to discuss potential MSc and PhD positions.
We often have opportunities for undergraduate students to join the lab as an Honours student, summer research assistant, or work study student. Email me and we can meet to discuss possibilities. It is a good idea to get in touch early because positions for Honours students are limited.
Contact me at roslyn.dakin[@]gmail[.]com
Dynamic Behaviour logo designed by Ru Ratnayake

title: Team
text:
Roz Dakin, Principal Investigator
I am fascinated by animal behaviour, how it works, and how it evolves. I completed my BSc, MSc and PhD at Queen’s University, and was a postdoctoral fellow at UBC and the Smithsonian. I am passionate about data and quantitative biology.

title: Research
text:
From dodging collisions to deciding how much effort to expend on offspring, behaviour provides a means for animals to respond to diverse challenges in nature. The goal of our research is to understand the mechanisms that have evolved to solve sensory, motor, and decision-making problems. Some of our recent interests:
> How animals use multiple cues to guide movement and decision-making
> The function and origin of movement behaviours
> How individual behaviours determine population-level processes
Understanding the mechanistic causes of behavior is necessary to anticipate and solve many applied problems in ecology. Natural behavioural systems can also provide inspiration for solving technological problems (after all, evolution is cleverer than you are). Our approach to animal behaviour often involves gleaning insights from high-throughput data.
Finally, we also aim to inspire broader interest and participation in science through our outreach and teaching activities.
